sp.p: Never mind about his hands - here you -

div.view: The other man takes the oar. He is a middle-aged, painfully thin and undernourished immigrant. Though he tries conscientiously to work the oar, it nearly tears him to pieces. Sally kneels in the boat, her shoulders slightly hunched. There is no sound for awhile a while , but the waves beating against the boat, and the whistling wind, blowing. They seem to be alone on the river. It is lighting up, but the drizzling rain has turned to sleet. After awhile, Sally asks:

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Thad --d’you suppose Ren reached Fort Vancouver?

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: If Ren Bullock set out for Fort Vancouver - he got there. Ren always does what he says he will do.

div.stage: The boat drifts on. The wind is dying down. The overcast skies gradually lighten.
div.view: Suddenly an exclamation escapes Sally. She almost stands up in the canoe in her excitement. Thad tries to steady the boat and calls out sharply:

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Look out! We’ll go over.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh, Thad - look--look - off there --

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: I don’t see anything

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: B-but--Oh Thad am I dreaming?

div.view: In a very long shot we see at a great distance, what looks like the shadowy outline of a ship. The Immigrant in the back of the boat stops paddling. His eyes seem to be starting from his head, as he too peers through the mist of the early day. Then he shouts:

sp.speaker: CHARLIE
sp.p: Praise be to God!

div.view: The oar drops from his hands and into the river. He kneels in the bottom of the boat raising his hands in prayer, and half singing, half praying, he rocks in an ecstasy. He has gone temporarily out of his mind. Thad, too, sees the vessel. His care now is all for the little craft with its one paddle oar, and he has his hands full steadying it, for they are in a rough part of the river.
Medium long shot of the ship. Ren is pacing its deck, restlessly.

Suddenly he stands stock still, his hands gripping the rail. From somewhere up the river, he hears a whistle. It is repeated three times. Three clear, familiar notes. For a moment Ren cannot believe he hears aright. His first reaction is one of powerful joy and exhilaration. His next - he remembers the last time he had seen his pal. Sally Lou raising her face to kiss him goodbye. Ren’s face hardens. He stares out before him.

Again the three long whistling notes. The man by the rail remains unmoving, but a curious change is breaking over his face. Something soft, tender, gentle, makes it as fine as the face of a mother. He leans forward. He purses his lips. Three times he sends back that whistling signal. Then,
K-4. as if springing to electrical life he rushes toward the Captain.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Do you hear that?

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Yes--some wild bird.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: No--not a wild bird. It’s my partner--my pal, Captain. He’s out there somewhere--in the river.

div.view: A few minutes later everything is activity aboard the vessel. Full steam is put on. As the ship proceeds, the sunshine breaks through the clouds, and in the glow far up the stream, tossing uponupon has been added in the original text. the turbulent water, they descry the canoe.

There is the business of taking Thad, Sally and the Immigrant aboard. Though cold and wet through, Sally’s eyes are luminous with happiness. The Captain, much concerned that a girl should have been exposed to such hardship and weather, begs her to go immediately to the cabin, but Sally is looking past the captain at the now sombre and stern Ren. Though he has helped them aboard he is standing back. Thad holds out his hand to him, and after a moment, Ren, without a word grasps it. The two men silently shake. Then Thad’s hand clasps the other on the shoulder. Thad starts to explain how they came to be on the river, and to tell about the plans of the Immigrants, but Sally comes up
K-5. beside him. She tries to entrap Ren’s glance, but Ren is afraid to look at her.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Thad--tell him later. I-I want to say something now. Ren!

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Yes maam ma’am .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I ran after you--the morning you left--Oh--ran and ran-- and I called to you-- didn’t you hear me?

div.p: Ren does not answer.

sp.p: I had something terribly important I wanted you to know.

div.p: Still Ren does not answer.

sp.p: You see----you see------

div.view: Now Ren can no longer avoid looking at her, for Sally has put one little hand on either of his arms, and her face is directly under his.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: You see---Thad’s my brother---

div.stage: Ren takes this big. So big that Sally catches her breath as she laughs.

sp.p: Yes--my brother--my big, bad brother.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Miss Sally---I reckon, I’m the most powerful dunce in Oregon.

div.view: Sally, looking at him, catches her breath in a laugh that breaks, and suddenly her eyes fill with tears -- tears of a long hurt, and of utter physical strain and exhaustion. She sways. With an incoherent murmur Ren takes her into his arms.

Further up the river a fleet of Indian canoes are coming. Each canoe contains about eighteen men, dressed in skins and sea otter, their hair powdered with the white dawndown of birds and their faces befogged with paint.

The Chief occupies a place in the middle boat and is distinguished by his high cap, ornamented with a tuft of eagle feathers. As they come down the river they beat time against the gunwhale gunwale of the boat with their paddles. They are chanting a war song, and at the end of each verse, they point with extended arms to the North and the South. There is no yelling or whooping; just the monotonous chanting, triumphant and bold. There are probably two hundred braves in the canoes, as well as the squaws who shriek in accompaniment, beating their hands together fiercely.
div.stage: On board the Hudsons Hudson’s Bay ship.
div.view: In the cabin Sally and Thad and the Immigrant are having their first meal since they set out in their crude canoe. Across the table from Sally sits Ren, his elbows on the table, his chin in his hands. He looks only at Sally, and his gaze is tender, devouring, adoring.
A sort of suddering shuddering motion of the boat, and then it stops. A couple of the ship’s men run past. The Captain’s voice is heard shouting orders. There is the clink of chains, etc.
Ren has started up. He is about to go on deck, when the Captain comes to the door.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: Nothing to worry about. We’ve gone aground; but we’ll get her off. Hello--what’s that?

div.view: Off - the voices of the Indians can be heard. Ren looks at the Captain; the latter, an old pilot of the Columbia says that they are probably to have some visitors. He exits on deck followed by Ren. Thad starts to go also, but Ren bids him remain with Sally; Thad walks about restlessly, moodily. He is apprehensive and worried.

The Indian canoes are now parading in a circle around the ship. The Captain and Ren are at the rail. The
K-8. Captain points out that these are Cayuse Indians, friendly to the whites. However, they are standing up in their canoes, their hands raised the peace sign.
div.stage: One of the Indians, who speaks English, calls out that a delegation of the chiefs would like to come aboard to trade buffalo hides for brass metals and knives.
The Captain, pleased, in spite of Ren’s uneasiness and suspicion, tells them to come aboard, and soon about fourteen of the braves climb aboard.
div.view: All unsuspecting the captain examines their buffalo hides, and gives them in exchange the desired brass buttons and knives.
div.sound: Suddenly one of them lets out a terrifying war whoop. This is immediately echoed by the others, while an answering roar comes from the men in the canoes below.
div.view: They rush upon the whites. The clerk is stabbed in the back. The Captain, sitting on the taffrail is clubbed and falls overboard, there to be knifed by the Indians in thecanoes the canoes . One big burly sailor fights for his life with his bare fists, before he is clubbed and stabbed to death.
Ren, his gun spitting fire leaps for the companionway and reaches the cabin. There he and Thad and the other men barricade themselves in.

The Indians pour down passageway the passage way . Ren and Thad cut holes for their fire arms firearms in the walls of the cabin, and pour out a withering fire of shot, that has deadly effect Missing ending punctuation .
Leaving their dead and wounded, the Indians flee back up the companionway.
It is now dusk, and the thin snow storm has become a dense one. The Indians scuttle across the deck, and go over the rail making for their canoes.
div.stage: IN THE CABIN
div.view: Sally is asleep. The Immigrant too is stretched out on the floor, dead to the world. Ren lights a ship’s lantern. He sets it on the table. In this flickering light he and Thad sit opposite each other. For a long time no word is spoken. Then:

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Indians never attack or fight at night. We can get away in one of the ship’s boats; they are all well-stocked.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: I’m thinking of our people. They’ll be on their way down the river. Those red devils know it. They’re waiting for them.

div.view: Thad’s head drops on his arms on the table. Ren reaches across and pats him on the head.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Brace up. This is no time to lose your nerve. I’m leanin on you, Thad.

div.stage: Thad gives him a singularly boyish look at that.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Are you, Ren?

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Of course.

div.stage: Thad swallows.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: You see, I never did amount to anything, and I’ve given my father all kinds of worry. Why--I’m to blame for the fix we’re all in now.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: How do you figger figure that out?

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: If I hadn’t gone on that drunk in Independence we’d’ve been the guides for the Train, and we’d’ve got through two months ago.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: They’ll get through yet.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Not if the Indians can stop them. I got a lot to answer for--a lot upon my conscience. Killing one man when we were in a fight is nothing compared to what’s happened to -- those Immigrants.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Come back here, Thad. sit down again. I want to speak to you.

div.view: Thad sits. Ren gives him an intent look. He lowers his voice as he slightly leans across the table, fixing the other with his steady regard.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: I been doin’ a powerful lot of thinkin’.

div.view: On the courch couch /choice> Sally stirs. Her eyes half open. At first she listens almost unconsciously; and then with tense interest and fear.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: There’s a big powder magazine aboard this ship ---

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Ye-eh--?

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: We gotta get rid of them Indians!

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Yeh!

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: If we don’t they’ll massacre our people! I say we gotta get rid of them Indians!

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: How can we! How can we!

div.stage: Ren lowers his voice.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: You all are goin’ on the ship’s boat as soon as it’s dark enough. I’m stayin’ here.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Stayin’ - herhere - alone you mean?

div.stage: Ren nods.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: What for?

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Soon as it’s day break, those Indians’ll be comin’ back - they’ll be comin’ aboard - well then -

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: If I touch that powder magazine off - the whole ship and everyone aboard it will be blown to pieces.

div.view: Sally is now sitting up. Thad is staring at Ren, his eyes widening with horror as he comprehends what Ren intends to do.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Whoever lights that powder magazine will be blown up himself, won’t he?

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: I’ll take care of that.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: No, by God! I will!

div.view: Both men have started to their feet.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: I’ll handle my own job.

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Not this time. I’ll do it.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: No, you won’t. You’re goin’ back to take care of your father. He’ll be needin’ you -- and your sister--- Sally ---

sp.speaker: THAD
sp.p: Nobody needs me. I can’t go back. Sooner or later they’ll get me. They’s a price on my head-- they’re lookin’ for me in every border town. I’d rather go this way--than--by the rope.

div.view: Suddenly Sally screams. She comes screaming in between them. She cannot speak. She can only cry. She clings to Ren. She clings to Thad. She keeps crying and sobbing. Ren, holding her in his arms, looks across at Thad. His face is stern, grave.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Sally, I’m goin’ to take you down the river a little ways. We’ll be meeting’ up presently with our people--

div.stage: Sally clings to him.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I won’t go without you!

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: I’m aimin’ to ‘scort you.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: And Thad--my brother--he shan’t stay here either. Oh, what a terrible thing to think of!

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: It is terrible. We’ll not talk of it any more.

div.view: He soothes her. After awhile, he gently puts a heavy coat about her.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Come, we better be driftin’. You go ahead, Thad!
Here, CharleyCharlie--come on now--wake up.

div.stage: He shakes the Immigrant awake.
div.view: They all go out through the dark passage and up the companionway to the deck. The men release the boat. It is a big roomy boat, seaworthy, and well-provisioned and stocked for an emergency. There is also in the rear a place for shelter and it is propelled both by oars and sail.

div.head: SEQUENCE L
div.p: On the boat. They have a hoisted small sail, A a stiff wind is billowing it out, but the current is against them, for they are going up stream, and they are making slow time.
div.stage: It is still quite dark, though drawing toward morning. Occasionally the voice of the Immigrant rises in a gospel hymn. He sings like a madman.
div.view: Ren is at the helm. Sally is at his side, crouched close to him, her eyes never leaving his face. He bends to draw her wrap closer about her. She shakes her head dumbly. His arms are all she needs. He holds her close. Her arms go around his neck. She says passionately:

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Promise me--you’ll never leave me now.

div.stage: There is a long, deep pause. Then Ren in a hoarse, steady whisper, replies:

sp.p: I must go back! It is the only way!

div.view: In the stern of the boat, Thad peers at the two in front. There is something very tense about him - something tense and cautious. He courches crouches farther down in the shadow of the sail.
The lovers are still in each others each other’s arms. Their faces are illuminated. Whatever may befall them, this moment is all their own.

Half kneeling, half couuching crouching , in the shade of the sail, Thad looks at them, and a smile breaks over the boy’s face making it singularly young and singularly poignant. Without a sound he swings over the side of the boat. He drops in the water.
Sally stirs in Ren’s arms. They can see each other’s faces now, for it is becoming lighter.
Suddenly Sally holds Ren back from her. A troubled look comes over her face--an expression of strange and almost psychic fear.

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Thad--Thad--I had a sudden feelin that Thad was not ---

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Don’t worry dear. Thad’s asleep.

div.view: Sally break away from Ren. She is still under some restless spell. She call calls :

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Thad! Thad!

div.p: There is no answer. Now her fear has communicated itself to Ren.
div.stage: He calls out roughly:

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Thad! Are you all right?

div.view: But Thad does not answer. Ren moves back to the rear of the boat. Sally comes behind him. She is holding to the side of the boat and half crawling, half climbing, over the impediments, the ropes, etc.
div.stage: Ren, in a stunned silence, is staring down at the empty place where Thad had been. His voice sounds strange. He scarcely knows that it is he who is speaking.

sp.speaker: REN
sp.p: Thad---has gone back--for us!

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh, no-no--no,--no! While we were there--while we were in each other’s arms--he--Oh, Thad-- Thad!

div.view: Ren places her on the seat, covers her gently, and then springs for the sail. A few words to the half cracked Immigrant to hoist the sail, which he cannot do, though he sits gibbering there, holding the rope. Ren swings the helm around. The boat turns, slanting, as the wind slaps at the sail. Then it steadies itself and we - FADE

div.head: SEQUENCE M.
div.stage: We fade in on the Hudsons Hudson’s Bay Vessel. It is still aground, and the waves are beating about it.
div.view: It is about five o’clock in the morning! The boat is entirely surrounded by Indian canoes. But the canoes are empty. The Indians are swarming over the deck. Not merely a delegation, but the entire tribe. They are going through the bales and sacks and boxes. They are eating and drinking and wrapping the stuffs about them, and there is great jubilation among them.

DISSOLVE to the powder magazine of the ship. Pressed up against the wall is Thad. He is listening to the Indians. Some of them are coming down into the hold. Thad shrinks back farther. There is a slight crackle as he lights the torch.

CUT TO - The ship’s boat. It is coming along at considerable speed. Both Sally and Ren are at the helm, but they are not in each others’ arms. Their faces are white and lined with fear. They are looking dead ahead. Suddenly the air seems rent as by some tremendous shock. The roar of a monster explosion is heard from one end of the river to the other.
div.stage: Note: (If desired, show the blowing up of the ship)

div.head: SEQUENCE N
div.stage: This shows the Immigrant train. Down the river, on rafts, on boxes, on crude boats, with a few of the prairie schooners, the Immigrants are coming down the river.

No saga or iliad ever penned could do justice to their heroism, courage and valour; for despite their privations and sufferings, they are coming along on this, the last lap of their journey, their faces still radiant with hope. They are singing!
div.view: Farther down the river, in their boat, Ren and Sally are seen coming. Sally’s face is illuminated - poignantly beautiful. Ren removes his hat. His head bows. FADE.
